item.title: Health Dept. to Freeze $10 Billion in Funding to 5 Democratic States
item.description: The funding pause could jeopardize child care and other programs that serve hundreds of thousands of households in California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Department of Health and Human Services spokesman cited “massive amounts of fraud” as the reason for the freeze, but did not provide evidence of fraud in four of the states.

item.title: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland
item.description: In a CNN interview, the top Trump aide also echoed the president’s intent to run Venezuela as he laid out a case for the United States’ controlling weaker states by flexing its military might.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, the White House deputy chief of staff, at the White House last year. Mr. Miller’s remarks were part of a broader rhetorical push in interviews to justify American imperialism and a vision for a new world order.

item.title: Trump’s Post About Slain Minnesota Lawmaker Dismays Her Children
item.description: The son and daughter of Melissa and Mark Hortman have asked the president to remove a social media post promoting a conspiracy theory about the assassination.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sophie and Colin Hortman stood behind the caskets of their parents, Mark and Melissa Hortman, after a funeral service in Minneapolis in June.

item.title: Why Trump Refused to Back Venezuela’s Machado: Fears of Chaos, and Fraying Ties
item.description: U.S. intelligence suggested María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, would struggle to lead the government. But her relationship with Trump officials had been souring for months.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado and her surrogate presidential candidate, Edmundo González, at a rally in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, in 2024.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds Prohibition on Trump’s Medical Research Cuts
item.description: The ruling on Monday upheld a lower court’s judgment in April that the Trump administration could not drastically slash funding from the National Institutes of Health.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Hailey Sadler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal court of appeals ruled that the Trump administration could not cut federal funding given out by the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: David R. Young, 89, Is Dead; Nixon Aide Helped Steer the ‘Plumbers’
item.description: He took part in White House machinations to stop leaks of classified information by overseeing an investigative unit that resorted to burglary. He then cooperated with Watergate investigators.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Six Big Political Questions for 2026
item.description: A wildly important midterm year is off to a chaotic start, with a raid in Venezuela, an uneasy economy and more. Here’s what we’re curious about.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Trump rally in North Carolina last month.

item.title: Justice Dept. Drops Claim That Venezuela’s ‘Cartel de los Soles’ Is an Actual Group
item.description: Last year, before capturing President Nicolás Maduro, the Trump administration designated a Venezuelan slang term for drug corruption in the military as a terrorist organization and said he led it.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro in 2024. In a revised indictment, the Justice Department abandoned its claims that “Cartel de los Soles” was an actual organization.

item.title: For Many Jan. 6 Rioters, a Pardon From Trump Wasn’t Enough
item.description: Some pardoned rioters have been rearrested. Others returned to poverty and mental health challenges. And many became consumed by resentment and demands for payback.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Dan Barry

item.title: Waymo Has Come for the Kids in Los Angeles
item.description: Because families have complicated schedules.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll and Mark Abramson
item.media:description: Elle Shim, 17, and Ilyssa Freedland, 16, use a robotaxi to grab lunch during a break from ballet practice.

item.title: White House to Present Updated Plans for Trump’s Ballroom
item.description: After pressure from preservationists, the administration is expected to present the plans to a planning commission and make them public for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: President Trump with a model of his proposed ballroom last month. Mr. Trump surprised many in October when he abruptly tore down one side of the White House to make way for the ballroom.

item.title: Congress Is Divided Over Maduro Raid After First Briefing
item.description: The classified session for congressional leaders and the top members of the intelligence, defense and foreign policy panels came two days after the military operation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration left lawmakers in the dark about the raid in Venezuela, a decision that President Trump has said was made out of concern that they would leak details of the operation before it was carried out.

item.title: Hegseth Starts Proceedings Against Sen. Mark Kelly Over His Remarks
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth blasted the senator for “seditious” remarks. Mr. Kelly said he had done nothing wrong and cited similar comments by Mr. Hegseth.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our laws are clear. You can refuse illegal orders,” Senator Mark Kelly, Democrat of Arizona, said in a message to active-duty troops last year.

item.title: Republican Lawmakers Like MTG Have Criticized Trump as They Depart Congress
item.description: It turns out that few things liberate Republicans to speak their minds about President Trump like the fact that they are departing Congress.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning

item.title: Man in Custody After JD Vance’s Ohio Home Is Vandalized
item.description: Authorities arrested a man early Monday and later charged him. The vice president and his family were away from the personal residence in Cincinnati at the time, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz, Kevin Williams and Ali Watkins

item.title: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz Abandons Re-election Bid, and Amy Klobuchar May Run Instead
item.description: Mr. Walz said a growing scandal over fraud in social services programs led him to abandon his run for a third term as governor of Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Reid J. Epstein and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz said a widening scandal over fraud in social services programs in Minnesota had persuaded him to end his re-election bid.

item.title: After Venezuela, Trump Offers Hints About What Could Be Next
item.description: President Trump’s comments about Greenland, Colombia and Cuba offered a glimpse of how emboldened he feels after the quick capture of Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Returning Home No Longer Seems Out of Reach for Venezuelans in Florida
item.description: The American seizure of Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, has instilled hope for change among some immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelans and Venezuelan Americans cheer, sing, and wave Venezuelan flags while celebrating the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, in Doral, Fla. on Saturday.

item.title: Supreme Court Increasingly Favors the Rich, Economists Say
item.description: A new study found that the court’s Republican appointees voted for the wealthier side in cases 70 percent of the time in 2022, up from 45 percent in 1953.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The study concluded that the Supreme Court has become deeply polarized in cases pitting the rich against the poor.

item.title: Trial Begins for Former Officer Over Uvalde School Shooting Response
item.description: Families of the victims and survivors of the 2022 elementary school shooting in Texas are expected to testify. Jury selection began on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial outside Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, in 2024. Jury selection is set to begin for the trial of one of the first officers to arrive at the scene of the massacre where a teenage gunman killed 19 children and two teachers.

item.title: Lia Smith Hoped to Start Fresh At Middlebury. In Trump’s America, It Seemed Impossible.
item.description: Lia Smith was a senior at Middlebury College, a transgender woman and, for a time, an athlete on the school’s diving team. But she struggled to feel accepted, and in October, she took her own life.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lia Smith’s body was found in a field near the Knoll.

item.title: The Key Senate Races to Watch in 2026
item.description: Democrats want to regain control of the chamber, and they have recruited some top candidates. But they are facing a tough map.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Jon Ossoff, Democrat of Georgia, and Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, will need to defend their seats.
